Headline: Kenyan Authorities Say Son of Official Was Among Gunmen in University Attack
Author: Jeffrey Gettleman and Isma’il Kushkush
C-deck: The identification of one of the gunmen in the attack that killed nearly 150 students as the son of a local chief near the Somali border rekindled fears of a homegrown terrorism problem.
Question: Abdirahim Abdullahi, one of the gunmen in the Kenyan university attack, quit his job at a Nairobi bank to do which of the following?
Correct answer: Become part of the Shabab Islamist militant group
Incorrect answer A: Go back to school at the University of Nairobi
Incorrect answer C: Join the Boko Haram Islamist militant group

Headline: Bulgaria Puts Up a New Wall, but This One Keeps People Out
Author: Rick Lyman
C-deck: The former Communist nation has completed 20 miles of fence along its border with Turkey, and plans to extend it to 100 miles, to stem the flow of refugees.
Question: Which of the following is NOT a reason why Bulgaria wants to build a fence along the Turkish border?
Correct answer: To encourage its citizens to remain in the country
Incorrect answer A: To end problems caused by the country's surge in immigration
Incorrect answer B: To reduce the likelihood of jihadists and foreign fighters entering the country
Incorrect answer C: To demonstrate that it should become part of the Schengen group of nations

Headline: Taking Feminist Battle to China's Streets, and Landing in Jail
Author: Andrew Jacobs
C-deck: The detention of five outspoken activists, part of an effort to quash the nascent feminist movement, is seen as a dismal milestone in the Communist Party's war on grass-roots activism.
Question: Five Chinese women are in jail because they were accused of provoking social instability. What were they planning when they were arrested?
Correct answer: A public awareness campaign about sexual harassment on public transportation
Incorrect answer A: A protest about inequality in higher education
Incorrect answer B: A demonstration about the indignities women face while waiting in line for the restroom
Incorrect answer C: A protest about the government's treatment of the LGBTQ community

Headline: Battling Crime and Calories at F.B.I. (Fit Bureau of Investigation)
Author: Michael S. Schmidt
C-deck: New fitness tests are in part a response to increasing concerns of senior F.B.I. officials about the toll on agents after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
Question: FBI Director James B. Comey thought that reinstating the bureau's mandatory fitness test would emphasize the important of all of the following EXCEPT:

Headline: 70 Years On, Crowd Gets Close to the Birthplace of the Atomic Bomb
Author: Rick Rojas
C-deck: Seventy years after the first test of the atomic bomb, tourists flock to the New Mexican desert.
Question: What is the birthplace of the atomic bomb known as?

Headline: California Seeks to Make Way for Statue of Sally Ride in U.S. Capitol
Author: Carol Pogash
C-deck: If legislators have their way, the statue will replace that of the Rev. Junipero Serra, the 18th-century Catholic priest, in the National Statuary Hall Collection in Washington.
Question: Which statue would California have to get rid of before it could build a statue of Sally Ride in the U.S. Capitol?

Headline: In Chicago’s Reshaped Politics, Unions Are Divided Over Mayoral Race
Author: Monica Davey
C-deck: Labor is vital to the chances of Jesus G. Garcia in Tuesday's runoff. But Mayor Rahm Emanuel is receiving a surprisingly solid amount of union support.
Question: Chicago mayoral candidate Jesus "Chuy" Garcia built his campaign on the backing of whom?

Headline: O’Hare Noise Complaints Influence Chicago’s Mayoral Race
Author: Mitch Smith
C-deck: Mounting frustration, and what some perceive as indifference from City Hall, has made plane noise a subplot in Tuesday's runoff election.
Question: Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel says he has done all EXCEPT what in response to the noise complaints surrounding O'Hare International Airport?
Incorrect answer C: Urged the FAA to speed up a process that would help residents pay for additional insulation

Headline: Wisconsin Supreme Court Election Raises Concerns About Partisanship
Author: Mitch Smith
C-deck: Ahead of the vote on Tuesday, out-of-state money has poured in, and harsh advertisements have filled the airwaves.
Question: Who is the incumbent seeking a third term in the Wisconsin Supreme Court election?

Headline: RadioShack’s Blueprint for a Rebirth, Planned by a Hedge Fund
Author: Hiroko Tabuchi
C-deck: Standard General, which will take over 1,700 of the 4,000 RadioShack stores, said that eliminating the retailer's heavy cost structure and some old business practices left a core worth saving.
Question: Which hedge fund is taking over 1,700 RadioShack stores?

Headline: China Escalates Hollywood Partnerships, Aiming to Compete One Day
Author: David Barboza
C-deck: Chinese studios are helping develop, design and produce world-class animated features and have ambitions to go global with their own.
Question: What movie marks the first collaboration between DreamWorks Studios and Oriental DreamWorks, its Chinese counterpart?

Headline: Greece and I.M.F. Hold Talks on Crucial Debt Payment
Author: Landon Thomas Jr.
C-deck: Greece's finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, and the International Monetary Fund's chief, Christine Lagarde, met in Washington as the due date neared for a 458 million euro payment to the fund.
Question: How much money (in euros) must Greece pay the International Monetary Fund on April 9?

Headline: Publication of New Internet Rules to Prompt Cheers and Challenges
Author: Rebecca R. Ruiz
C-deck: The F.C.C. regulations are expected to appear in the Federal Register as early as this week, starting two 60-day countdowns: one until they take effect and the other until a deadline for lawsuits.
Question: New Internet regulations approved in February will forbid all of the following except:
Incorrect answer A: Speeding up access to particular content
Incorrect answer B: Slowing down access to particular content

Headline: Online Test-Takers Feel Anti-Cheating Software’s Uneasy Glare
Author: Natasha Singer
C-deck: School administrators say for online learning to be legitimate, testing has to be monitored. Proctortrack is a new anti-cheating program being used by some universities.
Question: Which of the following is a software used to administer online testing?

Headline: Iran Is Raising Sophistication and Frequency of Cyberattacks, Study Says
Author: David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
C-deck: A new study concludes that Iran has greatly increased the frequency and skill of its cyberattacks, even while negotiating with world powers over its nuclear program.
Question: What have Iran's cyberattacks on the U.S. mostly involved?

Headline: UConn Too Big, Too Savvy and Too Much for Upstart Maryland
Author: Harvey Araton
C-deck: The Huskies and Coach Geno Auriemma, who are no strangers to the Final Four or the N.C.A.A. women's championship game, will play Notre Dame on Tuesday.
Question: Before this season, how many consecutive national titles had the Connecticut women's basketball team won?

Headline: Notre Dame Stifles South Carolina’s Gritty Rally to Reach Second Straight Final
Author: Jonathan Czupryn
C-deck: For the second season in a row and the fourth time in five years, the Irish will play for the women's national basketball championship.
Question: Who did Notre Dame's women's basketball team play after it beat South Carolina in the national semifinal?

Headline: Track’s Heartbeat Is Fast as Ever in Jamaica
Author: Michael Powell
C-deck: In Jamaica, whether the races feature Usain Bolt or a group of teenagers, running is a national obsession.
Question: What is the name of the Jamaica's five-day high school track competition?
